Content: -Denise Diller Well the original Aryans would have strongly resembled modern Europeans but they never existed in Europe. Indo-European tribes speaking Iranic and Indo-Aryan languages only started calling themselves that after they had left Europe and entered Central Asia. These proto-Scythians were the indigenous populace in many parts of Central Asia before other groups like Turks and Mongols moved in as well.
explanation: Likely critical or skeptical language.

Content:
-Hitler had no freaking clue what historical Aryans were about, it was mostly fantasy that later people tried to reconnect with historical "Aryans" (like most questionable studies on "Germania" from comparative mythology were written after the war). Germans were shocked when an actually Indian "Aryan Troops" turned up and did not treat them well at all although they were there to support them. 

That said, we do not know what historical Aryans looked like, they came from somewheresomewhere Central Asia and some texts mention red hair or green eyes. However, the history of colors is not so easy, colors are very psychological and vary wildely due to cultural and experiential factors. A hazel could have been green to them, a  auburn could have been considered red. Anyways, they were likely not one homogenous look because... why would them? They were moving around a lot that's not how you gain a homogenous look.
explanation: Sarcastic questioning ‚Äî likely expressing doubt or disbelief.

Content:
--Marijn Tak Most Conspiracy theories have selection built in as a feature.  Just like typos in scam emails.   It's intentional. 

 Political or ethnic conspiracies are even easier to get people on.  Build a conspiracy that pleads to someone's ego. Once you get someone to bite on the little stuff they have to chase the bigger stuff to avoid admitting their original position is wrong.    

Now you've got a few hundred people all racing each other to distance themselves from the original premise by burying it under layers of "evidence" and 'one up' the others position in the in-group.

Repeat a few layers and you've got fascism. 

Do it at a small scale and you've got 90s tv high school social structures :P.   "I didn't actually think Tammy slept with Brad."
explanation: Likely sarcastic criticism ‚Äî ironic disbelief or mockery of the fake news.

Content:
Ok but he's not wrong if he's talking about indo europeans. There was a group who called themselves aryans, who are today called indo-europeans who originated around what is today Ukraine. They spread out in multiple directions. One wave went into europe, another went into central Asia, especially into Iran and modern Afghanistan and from there moved into pakistan and india.

This group did exist and we can reconstruct their language by looking at the similarities between the languages of their descendents. Many in india, most in Afghanistan much of Iran and most of Europe can trace their ancestry to this group.

There are two countries currently named after them today. Ireland and Iran, both different ways of saying aryan land. We have a decent idea of how they lived based off what the greeks wrote about their descendents the synthains. They were semi nomadic pastoralists who rode horses had tattoos, heavily used iron and used marijuana during religious rituals.
explanation: Possible ironic endorsement ‚Äî sarcasm misinterpreted as belief.

Content:
-not really. If you look at the Central Asian territory that is not really hospitable for long term sedantery lifestyle, so most people in earlier history were pastoral/nomadic. They worked as a connector between north and south, east and west, it made sense to develop a lingua franca which would then further develop into its own thing whenver intensive contact ceased. Since Europe and Asia are connected, there was just more space to overlap and exchange than to isolate. Imagine it like a spider web, if you like: the center forming a nexus, which we also see in economic history (silk road etc.) or epidemic history (plaguuuuue). The further you go along the net lines, the more lonely do the language groups become because it was harder to reach them (peninsulas, coasts, valleys between mountain ranges). But over time new economic networks formed closer by and then languages exchanged again for a bit, but according to the same principle. 

It is not much different in Africa, actually. You have many many more individual and isolated languages but along the trade networks you find mixtures that over time partly isolated and then clustered again. 

The Americas are different because were settled by humans later from a limited choice of languages. Population density was comparatively low, people who traveled away were rarely encountered again and so languages isolated more but trade language clusters were more punctuated.
explanation: Likely sarcastic criticism ‚Äî ironic disbelief or mockery of the fake news.

Greek aristos is from the root r to fit together therefore "most fitting" and thence "best". In my opinion ƒÅrya is a derivative of ari- "other" cognate with Greek allos and the thing you do with the other is hospitality, and so ƒÅrya are those that participate in hospitality rites, and thus polite guest-host gift-exchange society.

Content:
--CC Smith all right, yes I thought you meant the descendants Iran/Alan, I said about the others that it was a misconception concurrent with the rise of nazim,

by IndoEuropeanists of that era conflating ethnic consciousness and the meaning of the root, but even after that not a lot of concensus was reached so we can hypothesize all we want üòÅ

and yes Ehre is connected to the "Indo-Slavic" side's version *is- to seek, (my language has the archaic version still as a dialectal term 'iskati' - to search)

through 
ƒìre  <-    *aiz≈ç   <-  *h‚ÇÇoys-√©h‚ÇÇ,
from *h‚ÇÇeys- (‚Äúto respect‚Äù)
interestingly into
*h‚ÇÇi-s·∏±√©-ti   ->  *iskƒÅÀÄtei  ->  *j—åskati

but I don't know about the very root of arya, it's quite contested and hard to pinpoint, to me ar- 'plough' sounds like some kind of semantic contamination with ar- 'to fit',  *h‚ÇÇer-

as in arable, cultivated land or person, see Sanskrit anarya -uncivilized, non-aryan,
and also Sanskrit ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•É‡§ï (av·πõk√°, ‚Äúsafe‚Äù, literally ‚Äúnot wild‚Äù), ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç (v·πõk√°-tƒÅt, ‚Äúsavagery‚Äù) from 'wolf'

which could be the ultimate source for both the Greek aristos and pIIr aryas, and could have been carried on by hospitality rites in which someone's best behavior, cultured manners would be praised,

which then under pressure from foreign groups became an inspiration for an endonym in the Aryan peoples, while just a description in the Greeks which later rose in prominence to mean the ruling class,

although there's another interesting example and that is Celtic *aryos (freeman, noble)
which could stem from the same tradition rather than be an invention of their own or it could be a later loan, although it's also connected to a Germanic : *arjaz (‚Äúdistinguished, esteemed‚Äù)
which brings us back to points the nazis would love to hear üòÇ

Content: --Marko Perkovicanarya can be a tricky form because it's not anƒÅrya which would be the an- negation of ƒÅrya, it's from possibly this short a an-arya. So what is short a arya? Well ari- in RV usually refers to the other clan or other clan Lord which threatens to subordinate our guy (svapati) in the coalition. The term aryah I think is a reanalysis of the genitive singular of ari "the Ari's (people) which is why in the later language arya- only refers to vaisyas not to rajanyas or brahmanas. But let me give you instead a very different etymon of anarya, it could be a-narya "unmanly" similarly an-rta- untrue has a double semantic of a-nRta "unmanly" that poets take full advantage of. Suffice to say it's a semantically complex affair. Sorry to wax prolix, I'm a Vedicist.

Content:
I mean.... here's the thing. There's *some* theoretical merit to this, but only insofar as, well, as the chart here is actually valid linguistic theory. All he's really done is append the name "Aryan" to a theoretical people group that propagated that language. Which, again, is actually historically what that word meant.

Problem is, post-Vril Society (precursors to the Nazis, you see,) the "Aryan" name takes on all this connotative meaning that it didn't have originally, because it was co-opted by yet another "[whatever the speaker is] supremacist" movement.

But really, all they actually did was the same shit people are doing today with their Baltic supremacist revisionist shit, or the hoteps trying to claim that every culture that did anything of note was actually black, or the Anglophiles saying.... pretty much anything that comes out of their stupid faceflaps. It doesn't actually obviate the idea that there was a group of people who we now call Aryans who propagated and spread and promulgated their language that eventually split to be pretty much all the languages west of the Indus Valley ü§∑
explanation: Likely sarcastic criticism ‚Äî ironic disbelief or mockery of the fake news.
